content.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is characterized by the presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both. Obsessions are recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images that are intrusive and unwanted, causing marked anxiety or distress. Compulsions are repetitive behaviors or mental acts that an individual feels driven to perform in response to an obsession or according to rigid rules. These behaviors aim to reduce distress or prevent a feared event, but are excessive or not realistically connected to the event. The obsessions or compulsions cause significant distress, are time-consuming, or interfere with daily functioning.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both. B. Obsessions and/or compulsions are time-consuming (e.g., >1 hour/day) or cause clinically significant distress/impairment. C. Symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition. D. Disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.
content.prevalence: 12-month prevalence about 1.2% in the U.S.; similar rates in males and females, though males have earlier onset.
content.age_of_onset: Bimodal onset — one peak in childhood/adolescence and another in early adulthood.
content.prognosis: Often chronic without treatment; early intervention improves outcomes. Many have waxing and waning symptoms. Good insight, lower baseline severity, and strong support are associated with better prognosis.

circuitry: Hyperactivity in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) loops, especially orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, and caudate nucleus.
neurochemistry: Serotonergic system dysfunction; possible glutamate dysregulation.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: First-degree relatives have increased risk; early-life stress, infection (PANDAS/PANS hypotheses) may contribute.

history_psychosocial: Specific obsessions and compulsions, avoidance behaviors.
Impact on school/work/home, relationships, and leisure.
medical_assessment: Assess for tics or neurological findings if relevant.
Screen for autoimmune or infectious triggers in suspected pediatric-onset (PANDAS/PANS).
risk_stratification: Assess for suicidal ideation due to comorbid depression or distress from symptoms.
evaluation.team_and_process: Interdisciplinary care with psychiatry, psychology, and when indicated neurology or pediatrics; involve family in psychoeducation and support.

obsessions: Fears of harming self or others

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms cause some distress but minimal interference with functioning.
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms cause clear distress and interfere with functioning, but manageable with effort.
severity_levels.severe: Symptoms are disabling and prevent normal functioning.

biological: Family history of OCD or related disorders

impact_on_life.school_work: Reduced productivity, absenteeism due to rituals or avoidance.
impact_on_life.medical: Skin damage from excessive washing, musculoskeletal pain from repetitive actions.

psychotherapy: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) — gold standard behavioral treatment.
Cognitive therapy targeting maladaptive beliefs about responsibility and threat.
medications: First-line: SSRIs (fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, sertraline, paroxetine, escitalopram).
Clomipramine — effective but with more side effects; monitor for cardiac and anticholinergic effects.
Augmentation: low-dose antipsychotics (risperidone, aripiprazole) for partial SSRI responders.
neuromodulation: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) for severe, treatment-refractory cases.
Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) targeting supplementary motor area.
lifestyle_interventions: Stress management, mindfulness, regular sleep and exercise.
care_coordination: Close monitoring of medication adherence and ERP participation.
Involving support network for encouragement and assistance.

treatment_goals: Reduce severity and frequency of obsessions and compulsions.
Improve functional ability and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing intrusive thoughts to psychosis without assessing insight.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling normative routines or preferences as compulsions.

insight: Good/fair insight: recognizes OCD beliefs are probably not true
Poor insight: thinks OCD beliefs are probably true
tic_related: Current or past history of tic disorder

warning_signs: Escalating distress and impairment from rituals
Skin lesions, infections from excessive cleaning
self_help_strategies: Gradual exposure to feared situations without rituals.
Self-monitoring of triggers and compulsive urges.

childhood: Magical thinking and rituals; possible comorbid tics.
adolescence: Increased time spent on rituals; school and social impairment.
adulthood: Chronic symptoms; occupational and relationship strain.

real_life_examples: A 25-year-old who washes hands 40 times a day due to contamination fears, leading to raw, bleeding skin.
A teenager who spends 3 hours nightly checking locks and appliances before sleeping.
A teacher with symmetry obsessions who rearranges desks repeatedly before class.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if obsessions or compulsions take more than an hour a day, cause distress, or impair functioning.

positive_factors: Strong adherence to ERP and medications
